block.p: Cherise Evette Trahan was married to Stephen Alexander Miller in a civil ceremony on June 16 at the Brooklyn Municipal Building. Last evening, Faybiene Miranda, a poet, led a ceremony combining African and Indian wedding traditions at the home of the bridegroom's mother, Audrey Bleviss, in Denville, N.J.

The bride, 31, and the bridegroom, 29, have taken the surname TrahanMiller. They are partners in Ashay Communications, a multimedia design concern in Brooklyn. She is the president, and he is the vice president for production.

Cherise Evette Trahan was married to Stephen Alexander Miller in a civil ceremony on June 16 at the Brooklyn Municipal Building. Last evening, Faybiene Miranda, a poet, led a ceremony combining African and Indian wedding traditions at the home of the bridegroom's mother, Audrey Bleviss, in Denville, N.J.

The bride, 31, and the bridegroom, 29, have taken the surname TrahanMiller. They are partners in Ashay Communications, a multimedia design concern in Brooklyn. She is the president, and he is the vice president for production.

The bride graduated from Webster University. She is a daughter of Mckinley Trahan and Helen Bean, both of Houston. Her father, who is retired, was a postal worker in Houston. Her mother teaches kindergarten at the J. Will Jones Elementary School there.

The bridegroom's mother is the senior editor of Catchafire.com, an online subsidiary of Ashay that features black artists. His father, Stephen C. Miller, is the assistant to the technology editor at The New York Times.
